nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Sitting Down at the Table
nodes.text: You and your co-parent sit across from each other. The air is stiff, but you both agreed: tonight is about making some basic agreements for your child, not re-arguing the breakup.

choices.label: Start with something positive about the co-parent.
choices.text: You begin: “Thanks for meeting. I know this isn’t easy, but I appreciate that you’re here.”

choices.label: Dive straight into the problems.
choices.text: You skip the warm-up: “This schedule is not working. We need to fix it.”

nodes.speaker: Co-Parent
nodes.title: What Matters Most?
nodes.text: Your co-parent shifts in their chair. “I just want things to be fair,” they say. “I feel like I’m carrying more than you.”

choices.label: Bring the focus back to the child and shared goals.
choices.text: “I hear that,” you say. “Can we make ‘what’s best for our child’ the main thing we check everything against, including what feels fair to us?”

choices.label: Argue about who does more.
choices.text: “You’re not the only one carrying things,” you fire back. “I’m doing school runs, meals, bedtime… it’s not like I’m on holiday.”

choices.label: Acknowledge the feeling and suggest making one small, concrete change.
choices.text: “It does feel lopsided sometimes,” you say. “What if we pick just one thing tonight that makes it easier on both of us?”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: Zooming Out for a Moment
nodes.text:
For a few breaths, the two of you sit with the word “fair.” It means different things to each of you: time, money, invisible labour.

Underneath all of it is a quieter question: “What would feel steady for our child?”

choices.label: Try putting one clear agreement on the table.
choices.text: You suggest focusing on one simple agreement you could both actually test in real life.

nodes.speaker: Mediator
nodes.title: Drafting the First Agreement
nodes.text:
You each scribble notes on a scrap of paper.

The mediator (or the calmer part of your own mind) nudges you away from grand solutions and toward something testable. One concrete agreement you could both try for a few weeks.

choices.label: Propose one small, specific change you can both trial.
choices.text: “What if we agree that handovers are always at 18:30 for the next month,” you suggest, “and if it’s not working, we tweak it together?”

choices.label: Try to fix everything in one big agreement.
choices.text: “Let’s just fix the whole plan tonight,” you say. “Bedtimes, holidays, money, new partners—everything.”

choices.label: Keep the agreement intentionally flexible and child-centered.
choices.text: “Let’s write one line we both agree on,” you suggest. “Something like: ‘We’ll adjust the schedule if our child starts to struggle, even if it’s inconvenient for us.’”

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.title: End of Scene – First Agreements
nodes.text:
By the end of the conversation, you haven’t redesigned your entire co-parenting plan.

But there is a first agreement on the table—or at least a clearer sense of why it’s hard to make one. The room feels a little less sharp around the edges.

choices.label: Pause here and return to menu.
choices.text: You decide that one step is enough for tonight.

choices.label: Take a moment to reflect on your own real-life agreements.
choices.text: You notice which lines in this scene felt close to home, and which choices you wish you could try in real life.

nodes.speaker: You
nodes.title: Quick Reflection
nodes.text:
If you were to write one real-life sentence about agreements right now, what would it be?

It might sound like:
“Even if we disagree, we’ll keep talking about the plan instead of using our child as the messenger.”

choices.label: Finish the scene.
choices.text: You close the scenario and carry that one sentence with you.

acts.title: First Agreements at the Table
acts.description: You and your co-parent try to turn vague complaints about “fairness” into one concrete, child-centered agreement.
